summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington today entered a final judgment against defendant Byron E. Scherf in a parallel criminal case.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Seattle, alleges that Scherf violated the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder and Section 17(a)(1) and Rule 17(b)(2) thereunder. The complaint also alleges that, contrary to the SEC's findings, Scherf was unlawfully held in the Snohomish County Jail for 22 days after he was arrested for the murder of Officer Biendl. According to the complaint, the defendants were not permitted access to the jail's books and records, and Scherf did not participate in the search. The SEC alleges that the defendants' statements were inconsistent with the facts of the case and were inadmissible because they were not consistent with Scherf's reasonable efforts to comply with the requirements of the federal securities laws. In addition, the complaint alleges that when Scherf requested an attorney, he was repeatedly interrogated and reminded that he had previously invoked his right to an attorney when he was incarcerated for a prior felony. The court also found that the defendant did not provide reasonable assistance in determining whether he was entitled to a fair trial. In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against Scherf. The case is being handled by Scott M. Welshhans, Chief of the Division of Criminal Investigations, and Assistant Director of the Office of Public Safety. The litigation will be led by Timothy J. Burt and supervised by Amy S. Cotter.Â  The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in this matter.
